elements.name: requiredChanges
elements.title: Are there changes that could be made to the order, or a different order about the same thing, that you would agree to or you would like the court to make?
elements.description: You may not agree with the order the other party is asking for or there may be a different order about the same thing that you would agree to the court making.</br></br>For example, if the other party is asking for you to exchange a copy of your financial documents on March 31st of each year, you may agree to exchange the documents but only if the date is April 31st each year.</br></br>An example of different order about the same thing may include that the documents be exchanged by email whether you agree or not to the order to exchange the documents.</br></br>Remember that you can only ask for changes to the proposed orders or orders about the same issue that is before the court, for example, case management, enforcement, protection order terms, etc., in the application you are replying to.

elements.name: FAQ
elements.title: What if I want an order about something else?
elements.body: It is not uncommon to need a different, but maybe related, order after being served with an application. In the example above, you may realize that you need to change the child support order because it no longer reflects your new incomes.</br></br>To ask for an order about something else, you will need to file your own application to bring the issue before the court. You can complete and file the application using this service by selecting Apply for an Order in Step 1 – Getting Started and then select each option you want to ask the court for an order about under the Apply for an Order sub-step.</br></br>You can also try to resolve the issue out of court. Click on Get Help along the top banner of this service for information and resources about where to resolve a family issue out of court.

elements.name: orderDescription
elements.title: Please provide the details of the order you are asking the court to make:
elements.description:
You do not need to use any special wording. The key is to be clear about what you mean and what you are asking the court to order.

Remember that you can only ask for orders about the same issue that is before the court, for example, case management, enforcement, protection order terms, etc., or changes to the proposed order in the application you are replying to.

The Provincial Court’s Family Law Act Picklist includes commonly used order terms that might be helpful.

elements.name: FAQLegalAdvice
elements.title: I’m not sure what order I need. Where can I get legal assistance?
elements.body:
Understanding the law and making sure you get correct information is important. If you get the wrong information or do not know how the law applies to your situation, it can be harder to resolve your case. Getting advice from a lawyer can help.

Lawyers: To find a lawyer or to have a free consultation with a lawyer for up to 30 minutes, contact the Lawyer Referral Service at 1-800-663-1919

Legal Aid, Duty Counsel and Family Advice Lawyers: To find out if you qualify for free legal advice or representation, contact Legal Aid BC at

1-866-577-2525.


Legal Services and Resources: Visit Clicklaw at www.clicklaw.bc.ca/helpmap to find other free and low-cost legal services in your community

elements.name: applicationFacts
elements.description:
Give a short summary of the facts you want the court to consider when they are making a decision about the application. You do not need to use any special wording. The key is to be clear about what you mean and why you are asking the court to make the order.

If you disagree with the order the other person/party is asking for, what facts support the court not making the order? If you have also proposed another order, what facts support making a different order instead?
